comments.commentBody: The timer may have been turned off deliberately.  There is little point in using the timer on a locked puzzle.  You never really know when it's finished!

We live in a strange country. We obsess about Ebola that has infected only four people in the country but can't appoint a Surgeon General because he thinks something that kills over 30,000 Americans a year is a public health problem .
If anybody finds a way to make money infecting people with Ebola, look out.

I agree with you that all airports should be a concern, but a bigger concern of mine is the southern border.  The government is charged with protecting it's citizens and I think there would be bipartisan support for closing the border.

Yes, there are many contagious diseases.  But focusing on one in particular that is just getting started in Europe and the USA is not foolish.  All diseases have beginnings:  the objective is to quash this one before it takes hold.  I think that's a sensible and good thing to do.

"at least 18 cases have been treated in Europe and the United States." OK, not good. But, really? Are you serious? With a world full of contagious disasters, this is what we focus on? I am all for serious screening and sending millions of $ to those affected by Ebola in Africa. But in terms of the worlds greatest problems this only qualifies as the most hysterical.
Here is an idea: we send to death thousands of people and who knows how many others we alter via hormone and antibiotic fed animals that we eat.
Ebola is bad, really bad. But worse is the antibiotic resistance we are creating. NY Times: get some perspective...someone, please.

Christie and Cuomo are dead wrong. But for the moment, the deaths will be in Africa, and those people can't vote for either governor, so they don't count.

I can hardly imagine a more opportunistic disease than Cuomo and Christie. They test positive for pandering to fear. And they are highly infectious. Shame on them! Their political careers stand in the way of their judgment.

It is easy to make a scape goat out of the CDC, which was sending out informational packets asking for preparedness training in hospitals for six months prior to Mr. Duncan's arrival! Did Texas Presbyterian comply? No!
Did its ER staff turn away a patient they should have immediately isolated? Yes! Did the precautions for personal protective gear in health care workers change? Yes! -- The situation was evolving! The CDC PROPERLY responded as the situation changed: Ebola had never before been treated in an American hospital and CDC had to modify guidelines! They did! And oh by the way . . . is CDC underfunded? Yes! Thanks to the GOP -- let them bask in all their glory!

People who make a witch-hunt out of the CDC and the President (who is one of the most rational thinkers and careful responders this crisis has yet revealed) have checked their sanity at the door.

"The CDC has failed utterly and completely."

Based on one traveler from Liberia infecting two nurses? You can't be serious.

"Urgent and accelerating crisis?"
Three cases?
You have the wrong continent.

With containment and contact tracing, outbreaks have been easily stopped in Africa, before they got out of hand. This one is harder, hitting isolated rural areas, and overwhelming the Liberians and others capabilities. With the continued "urgent and accelerating crisis" there, Ebola will have an opportunity to mutate the longer and deeper the outbreak goes, and indeed might then become the 'urgent and accelerating" crisis for the world that is feared now.

How does it feel to have contributed in some small way to that un-hoped for eventuality, America?

"Mr. Christie...said...'We are no longer relying on C.D.C. standards.'"

Christie is correct on this issue.

The CDC has failed. Utterly and completely. The CDC has issued scientifically unprovable and scientifically disprovable false statements. The CDC has supported epidmiologically unsound and criminally negligent policies and protocols. The CDC has forfeited all credibility.

The CDC management--from the lab-head level to the Director level--needs to be dismissed, and the CDC mission needs to be re-assessed.

In the interim, with the collapse of credibility of the CDC and the abdication of responsibility by the White House (which, unaccountably, continues to reject travel restrictions), it is necessary for state and government officials to step in the the void created by federal failure and to address this urgent and accelerating crisis.
We cannot quarantine the whole world forever, and if this means fewer medical personnel go to West Africa to stop this disease, then these politicians have done us a disservice.
The American public doesn't know what that would entail or the consequences of that action.
The American public is remarkably uneducated. Do you mean the climate change deniers? Or the creationists? Or just those who cannot read, write, or do basic math?

Way too little too late.  The American public has been demanding a total cessation of public travel from the 3 countries that have massive outbreaks for weeks.   The common sense of the ages tells you to quarantine the outbreak where it is, not bring it to another continent!  Madness.

I don't think imposing quarantines is fear-mongering and not everything should be seen as having only political motivation. Rather, what these two governors have decided is the right and sensible thing to do and if this policy errs on the side of caution, what's so bad about that? As for witless and self-serving, rather than appropriate, are you a medical doctor to judge this. Here is a comment an actual medical doctor who says he has treated Ebola made yesterday; I think he agrees that Spencer and others should observe a quarantine:
Jack Midwest:
As a physician who has taken care of an Ebola patient lately, I will say one thing: Dr Craig Spencer is an idio@! for endangering so many lives. We have self quarantined ourselves after exposure to these patient(s).
The NY medical board should take a good look at his activities and his medical license and at the very least, publicly rebuke him.
Jeez! How irresponsible can you be?

"Political hack" doesn't even begin to describe the utter disgust and revulsion that Tweedle Dee and Tweedle Dum arouse in me over this issue. I am enraged at the gross self-serving nature of their political opportunism!

Where are the statesmen and stateswomen? I want to vote for someone who isn't mired in self-interest.

It is not protection for the American public to put obstacles in the path of returning health care workers from Africa! This just speeds the ultimate arrival of Ebola at our doorstep. As has been pointed out -- if the virus is permitted to get out of control in Africa (which it appears to be doing at this very moment) it will eventually arrive here in waves so large that it will be uncheckable and untraceable. You will have to quarantine people from every nation on earth!

The self-monitoring that was in place was entirely sufficient! If a doctor or nurse spends 4 weeks in Africa . . .

Mario Cuomo and Chris Christie insist that people shouldn't panic, then act like they're panicking themselves. What they're really doing, of course, is promoting their own political careers. Vile.

Worse, what medical professional will go to the African nations suffering most from the Ebola outbreak when they know that witless, self-serving political hacks like Cuomo and Christie are over-reacting back in the US?

The United States is being shamed by nations it condemns, most notably Cuba. Then it is shamed again by the idiocy of fearmongering politicians. Cuomo and Christie should be ashamed, but they would have to be capable of feeling shame.
I told an acquaintance the other day that she had a better chance of winning the lottery than contracting Ebola.  Enough with the fear mongering.

Apples and oranges!

We are not living in Guinea or Liberia. We don't eat bats for protein. In this country, at the present time, we can easily and thoroughly trace contacts of and isolate them without immobilizing our medical volunteers. Most of us don't believe that disease is a sign of witchcraft. And most of us comprehend basic hygiene and have access to toilets.

All viruses mutate as they multiply. It takes millions and millions of random mutations -- maybe billions -- before a virus hits upon a mutation that will produce an augmentation of its infectiousness. If we continue make it difficult for people to go to Africa to control the disease, we will be giving the virus a great opportunity to do just that!

Safety comes from knowledge. There is no safety for us in closing borders. All borders are ultimately porous.

The CDC doesn't have a political agenda its only agenda is about the control of disease. The fact that the CDC's orginal protocols were inadequate does not mean the agency is political.

The CDC should have looked to MSF for procedures they were wrong not to. Many agencies and companies are biased against solutions that aren't "built here." The CDC has made the adjustment.

I have more faith in the CDC than politicians running for reelection or trying to score political points.

I want to remind my fellow readers that it wasn't many weeks ago that the comments on Ebola articles was filled with it's an African problem why should we help sentiment. I'll skip the sarcastic rejoinder.

Perhaps we can remember that these two politicians are positioning themselves to run for president in 2016. They are engaging in Ebola drama for the optics. They are lawyers. What qualifies them to dismiss protocols established by the  CDC and Doctors Without Borders? They are not leaders. Leadership would be Andrew Cuomo revealing his position on fracking BEFORE the election. It's easier to surf Ebola hysteria.
To the outside world (as a Canadian living overseas), he seems to be a bystander on every issue...
This should have been done weeks ago at the federal level.  At least these two governors are showing some leadership.  I voted for Obama twice, but he just seems to be a bystander on this issue.

To patalcant

Then the government of Texas should have been on the ball. That is where the fault lies.
You'd better hope that they do not follow suit. The last thing we need is an even greater shortage of aid workers due to some needless hysteria.

I can only hope the federal government finally follows suit.

The one thing our experts should have concluded by now is that their previous certainties regarding the contagion represented by Ebola was mistaken. The hadn't even tracked the health care workers for Duncan, so sure were they before that they could not contract it -- yet two of them did.

And when we don't know the real risks, an abundance of caution is especially called for.

As the husband and father of doctors, I have a problem with politicians and newsreaders making policies based on a cycle of hysteria and not science.
Our politicians, after taking the country into debt on a war of choice based on lies--and financed abroad--and fought in part by expensive mercenaries--claim to have discovered "fiscal responsibility" by starving the sciences, NIH, and the CDC.
Dr. Spencer followed ALL applicable protocols, and monitored his temperature. It was 100.3 degrees F, and he began to have diarrhea, when he was transported to the Bellevue isolation unit. I do not think he was either febrile (and this is a LOW-GRADE fever) or diarrheic when he had contact with his girlfriend or bowled.
Medical evidence of ebola reveals it is spread by bodily secretions and excessive excretion (diarrhea) as the body attempts to get rid of it--not by a handshake. People such as Dr. Spencer know--and most of us should--that you should wash your hands after you wipe your rear after defecating to prevent not only ebola, but other feces-borne infections.
Reason...and not hysteria (nor the not-so-subtle racism expressed by grandstanding politicians such as Darryl Issa) are what is in order now.
Answer : The pride comes before the fall. The rules don't apply to such exceptional individuals.

It's a little early to say that self quarantine 'has fallen flat', isn't it? Or are you presuming that he has infected someone in the bowling alley?
And, speaking of presumption ... you know better than the CDC 'how an epidemic starts'?
The best precaution for stopping an epidemic from starting in North America is to stop the epidemic in West Africa. You cannot imagine that incarcerating the medical professionals who go there upon their return is the best way to help out.
Even in times of national panic, someone can come up with a better idea.

I trust the scientists...If a stringent quarantine policy inhibits the number of doctors necessary to go to the hot spots in Africa to save lives and eradicate the problem at its source, we ALL suffer.  A policy that harms this effort does no country any good ultimately.  The cost in lives, American, African and throughout the world, will be far greater.  This is no time for political positioning and scare tactics.

"Common sense" would have us still believing that the earth is the center of the universe . . . you know, that thing about the Sun rising in the East and setting in the West . . .! After all, that's common sense!

Common sense is not a substitute for either science or practical, hands-on experience.

The steps taken by the states of NY and New Jersey are what my grandparents used to call "using your noggin". Common sense, for once is finally beginning to seep back into our North American culture. While we should always do the utmost to help and give positive direction to countries in need of our assistance, we should definitely remember the adage that charity begins at home. Love all humanity but please, first, keep the men, women and children in the United States and Canada safe from any possible harm.
To those that believe we are over-reacting—that the crisis at the moment does not warrant this quarantine action being put forth—I say you are as blind as to how an epidemic starts as you are sincere in your beliefs of the rights of freedom of everyman. Taking great precautions to stop this disease before it becomes an epidemic in North America is also the right that all of us share. The right to live in an environment that is free from a dangerous, life-threatening disease that can and should be contained.
I too applaud the actions of Dr. Spencer in helping victims of Ebola. Not many of us would ever dream of putting ourselves in such a dangerous environment. But having done so, he showed little common sense upon his return to the U.S.
The argument that professionals coming back from Ebola-infected countries should be allowed to quarantine themselves of their own accord has fallen flat on its' face with just this one man.

It is widely understood China stole the high-speed rail technology it markets to the world from Japanese company Kawasaki Heavy Industries. Theft is not innovation. The overwhelming bulk of patents in China are small modifications of existing patents. Only a very small fraction of patents which originate in China are marketed abroad, some indication of their value.

Alibaba is thus far a brilliant business success, but cannot be chalked up as a pure Chinese innovation. Instead, it is better understood as an adaptation and blend of existing Western business models like Amazon.com, EBay and others.

Party propaganda is one thing--reality is another. Don't get lost in the hype.

I'm sorry, but when I go into a bar I do rate it on an absolute scale. Either, "This place looks good," or, "How did I wander into the American Kennel Club by mistake?" After that, if I stick around, I might rate the appropriate others relatively, but I still have an "absolute" standard which may suffer from a certain inadequacy of observation. I've never gone to bed with an ugly woman, but I've sure woken up with some.

While I don't recall your particular comment on the earlier Blindauer, DYT, I do remember that some of the criticisms were expressed in a less than respectful manner. (I didn't care for that puzzle either, but I tried to say so politely.)

I'm delighted to see this post. A genuine apology is a beautiful thing.

Howie--

Where I grew up, my high school's teams used to play Quincy. (This would be in the 1970's.) They were just as formidable in basketball as you are on this blog.

Oh, Wow! DYT, I dare say, that is high praise, indeed!
I certainly appreciate your saying that, however, I only arrived in Quincy 8 years ago to be near my grandchildren, after having lived in NYC for most of my life.

Have a swell weekend up there in Minny!

Howie

As one of the people who jumped all over the controversial Patrick Blindauer puzzle a couple of months ago, I've been gradually feeling more and more guilty and looking for a chance to apologize. This is it. Mr. Blindauer, I over-reacted then and was rude about expressing it.

In any event, I enjoyed the puzzles this week and MAY have solved the meta challenge (about which I will say nothing more, of course). I greatly appreciate the work this must have taken. Bravo!

I agree also with the quarantines and commend the Governors for taking steps that the Federal Govt. should have taken at least 1 month ago. The signal failure of the Obama Admin. to provide needed aid to W. Africa in late July and early August when the increasing danger of the current Ebola epidemic in Africa became apparent is appalling. They needed temporary hospitals and isolation wards then, and building them should have started then. This would have saved many lives in Africa as isolated good care can dramatically reduce rates of transmission of Ebola and sometimes increase the survival rate of those who are infected if they are kept hydrated and free of other opportunistic diseases that can weaken their immune systems as they try to recover.

I think that the failure of the President and Dr. Freiden to address the problems in Africa early resembles their failure to address the transmission of the disease here. Why did the CDC say there was a protocol for treatment that should have been used at the Texas Presbyterian Hosp. when in fact, as a national nurses union has complained, there was no such protocol delivered to nurses or to hospitals? My guess is that all of these problems have their root in some serious inability to manage.

The idea that many doctors and nurses will not volunteer to go to Africa if they will be subject to a quarantine when they return is nonsense. Surely they would be worried about transmitting the disease to their families.

I agree with the mandatory quarantines imposed by Givernors Cuomo and Christie.  The risks associated with Ebola and the high population densities near JFK and Newark Airports mandate this course of action, however unpleasant.

It's not just the NRA it's the culture. 2 office holders in Colorado lost their jobs because they passed such a bill. Nothing will change. Even the repeated slaughter of children is of no consequence. Where I live there's no fear of the home break in. We be in New England.

Sure, there are people upstate that are upset by the Safe Act.  And there are people in the City who are too.  I and a Democrat and live in upstate NY. Stereotyping upstate residents in general as gun-lovers is simply inaccurate.  Cuomo is disliked for many other reasons.  His bullying,  his cutting off school aid to upstate public schools, his continued preference for charter schools, his tax breaks for corporations and the rich, his unethical behavior, his dismantling of all ethics reform, his cozying up to Republicans to the detriment of Democrats, his mortician-like demeanor, and I could go on and on.
The Commander-in-Chief needs to issue no order to go about armed if he wishes.

The NRA specifically--or, perhaps, the lobbying industrial complex in general--seems to believe they are the fourth branch of government. And, since they seem to have their way with the Legislative and Judicial Branches, I guess they are.

The only way gun control legislation can get under way is if the President rules by Executive Order that he can brandish a pair of six guns and walk around like Marshall Matt Dillon. I believe action will follow.
The term "military-style" speaks volumes.

Nice list of people who should be banned from owning a gun, not stopping at felons, you've gone right down the line to misdemeanors...how about adding anyone you don't like, or who disagrees with you?
I support gun ownership as a way of exercising my second amendment right. I too am troubled by all of the gun violence, but do not think out right bans are the way to go (btw, the most recent school shooting, terrible as it is, was done with a pistol, not any "assault" rifle and was obtained via the family, who I assume had every legal right to posses one).
What you (and the other anti gun people really want is an outright ban on all guns), if that is the case, work on repealing the second amendment. I'm sure once you are successful in that Endeavour, all of these "second amendment" arguments we are having will go away....just be careful what you wish for, as governments can become oppressive over time, the founding fathers knew this all too well, which I believe was one of the driving reasons they stuck that pesky amendment in there....but that shouldn't stop you from going ahead and having it repealed.

I cannot fathom how anyone can justify an opinion holding that no gun regulation is permissible. The Second Amendment does not impose such an absolutist restraint on our government.

We once had a consensus in this country that firearms were a proper subject of regulation. You couldn't walk around town carrying a combat weapon, for example, and we even kept felons from having guns!

The nation needs much stronger background check laws, a renewed ban on military-style weapons of any kind, caps on the capacity of bullet magazines for semi-automatic weapons that fall outside the scope of that ban, and a total ban on armor-piercing bullets. Guns should be absolutely forbidden in any government building, in any public or private school, on any college campus, in any hospital, in or on any public land not open for hunting, and in any form of public transportation. Felons must be barred for life from owning a gun. So must people on probation, people convicted of misdemeanor domestic abuse or assault, and individuals subject to a domestic relations order of protection issued by a state court. Verifiably mentally ill individuals must be forbidden to own a gun.

These are common sense proposals. Too bad Congress is so addicted to blood money from the NRA and its allies, and too frightened to offend those radicals, to even consider them.

We're unfortunately likely to lose many more Americans to the needless scourge of gun violence until the fools that dominate Congress wake up.

Jon F---I am forced to agree with you on every count. Interleague play makes the World Series meaningless and the pursuit of TV revenues has caused MLB to ramp up an already too-long playoff scheme and has thrown in the second rate Wild Card teams into the mix as if the playoffs weren't long enough or complicated enough already.

As for the regular season, there is too much baseball on TV. Call me a fossil, but baseball is better rendered on radio where one has to give total attention to the proceedings and not vege out in front of a TV. Receiving the treat of the World Series on TV--during the day--made it mean something more than just another run of games as it is today.

Would Game 6 of the 1975 World Series seem as magical as it was then if it were played today? Discuss...

Many factors, some of which are not mentioned in the article have contributed to the decline of the World Series.  MLB, in its eternal quest for every last dollar, has damaged their product to the extent that most people choose to no longer watch it.  The changing demographics of the U.S. was not mentioned in the article.  Interleague play is common and occurs almost every day.  The World Series was special in large part because the two leagues never played each other in any games that counted.  Because MLB wanted the temporary infusion of money from Yankees-Mets, Cubs-White Sox, and Dodgers-Angels, it really cheapened the World Series.  MLB has also allowed the networks to pack extra commercials into games that are already too slow in terms of pace and too long in terms of time.  Go to youtube and watch a World Series game from the 1950's.  It's hardly the same game.  MLB has also lost a whole generation of younger fans with a couple decades worth of late starting times.  These people are not coming back.  MLB has been reaping lots of cash rewards from local cable companies and stations desperate to fill programming hours with live sports because live sports are about the only events that are DVR proof these days.  But the glory days of the World Series are gone forever and MLB has only itself to blame.

Huh? These fools, as you call them, are immensely rich people. I think they know what they're doing with their money. And no, they didn't vote for Di Blasio. And no, what Di Blasio has nothing to do with this.
I presume the fools paying these prices also voted for de Blasio!!
15.3% is the total- employer pays half, employee pays half. Also, this has been the case for many decades now, so it can hardly explain what's going on now.

The tax on jobs and workers has had a slow gradual effect. This is reflected in the slow gradual decline of family wealth. It has hurt the middle class and has devastated the poorer half of the country. In 1995 this large group of 62 million families shared 3.6% of the wealth. They now share only 1% of the wealth. This played a big role in Janet Yellen's speech on inequality on October 17, 2014. We need to look at the long term effects of bad tax provisions because they man not show up in the short term.

The intellectual property that underlies monopoly power has been purchased and consolidated so there is not much left to invest in. There are often only a handful of big players in each industry. Businesses that use labor rather than monopoly power are less profitable due in part to the tax code that adds 15.3% payroll tax to each U.S. job.
Replace the payroll taxes and full employment, higher salaries and economic growth will follow. Apple might consider U.S. manufacturing and stop worrying about using its vast reserves to buy back its own stock.

Interestingly, some research shows that lack of easy means to kill oneself leads to fewer suicides because some suicides are impulsive.  By the time a person contemplating suicide obtains the means to do it, if they don't have that, they sometimes have changed their mind.
